At that time, there were five hundred fishermen living together by the Ganges River.
At that time, the fishermen had two large nets:
One was called Small Foot, the other was called Big Foot.
If there were few buyers of fish, they would use Small Foot, if there were many buyers of fish, they would use Big Foot. If there was a big festival, they would use both nets.

At that time, in the city of Kuru, there was a great festival, and many people bought fish. Two nets were used together, and the five hundred people were divided into two groups, each holding one net. Those with small feet caught many fish, turtles, alligators, and other creatures, which were piled up on the shore like a large heap of grain.
At that time, there was a large makaras fish sleeping in the ocean. Following the tide, it drifted into the Jyotiá¹£ka River. Those with large feet immediately caught it in their net.

At that time, the two hundred and fifty people together pulled on the net. As the net constricted the body of the fish, it immediately woke up from sleep and dragged the net and people along with the current. They all became greatly alarmed and called out to the people with small feet, saying:
We, along with the net, are being dragged by the fish. You should all come together to help us.
When they heard this, they all came to pull together, but the five hundred people could not hold back the net as it went along with the fish.
At that time, the five hundred people cried out in loud voices and told the people nearby:
All of you should know that the five hundred of us, along with the large fishing net, were all dragged by the fish and flowed downstream together, coming to help each other.

At that time, the nearby residents, whether they were people who raised cattle and sheep, people who gathered firewood, people who lived by the right path, people who lived by the wrong path, and all the other people, hundreds of thousands and millions, all came to pull the net.
At that time, the bodies of those people were injured, the net was torn, and it was extremely difficult to pull it up onto the shore.

The makaras had eighteen heads, thirty-six eyes, some with human heads, some with elephant heads, some with horse heads, camel heads, donkey heads, ox heads, monkey heads, lion heads, tiger heads, leopard heads, bear heads, brown bear heads, cat heads, deer heads, buffalo heads, pig heads, dog heads, and fish heads. At that time, the people from the four directions passed on the message to each other:

On the banks of the River of Wisdom, five hundred fishermen had set a large net and caught a fish that was pulled up onto the shore. Its form was strange and large, with eighteen heads and thirty-six eyes.

When the people heard this, at that time there were countless hundreds of thousands of koá¹­is of nayutas of beings who flocked to the river, some with joyful feelings going there to observe, some with their past good roots awakened to go.

With a sense of wonder, they pointed and stayed.
It is the constant dharma of the buddhas to observe the world, to see and hear nothing, to know nothing, always giving rise to

At that time the World Honored One had this thought:

This makaras fish is now suffering a great calamity. In the past, under the Buddha, he has already planted roots of goodness. Because of this fish, I will set up a great teaching net to transform and deliver sentient beings. I should go to the bank of the Jyotiá¹£prabha River.

It is the constant practice of the Buddhas that, before entering nirvana and abiding in the world, out of compassion for the beings to be guided, they sometimes go to the realms of animals, hungry ghosts, humans, and gods, or to charnel grounds or river banks.

At that time, the World-Honored One caused those beings to give rise to faith, and then manifested other signs. Having seen those signs, they all thought:
We did not die here and be reborn elsewhere, but rather it is definitely due to the power of the unsurpassed great sage's virtue and virtue that we now experience physical and mental comfort.

Having given rise to reverence and faith, they were able to extinguish all suffering, and in the realms of humans and gods they received excellent and wonderful bodies, and became vessels for the Dharma, seeing the principle of true reality.
Those who ascended to the highest heaven of the form realm, in the light they expounded the Dharma of suffering, emptiness, impermanence, no-self, and so forth, and also spoke two verses, saying:
You should diligently seek the path of liberation within the Buddha's teachings,
Able to destroy the army of birth and death, like an elephant crushing a grass hut.
Within the Buddha's teachings and precepts, be courageous and always practice and study,
Able to abandon birth and death, and reach the end of suffering.
Then that light universally illuminated the trichiliocosm and returned to where the Buddha was.

In the past, during this fortunate eon, when the human lifespan was twenty thousand years, a World-Honored Buddha appeared in the world, called Kasyapa Tathagata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened, Perfect in Knowledge and Conduct, Well-Gone, Knower of the Secular World, Unsurpassed Person, Tamer, Teacher of Gods and Men, Buddha, World-Honored One, who was dwelling in the Deer Park of the fallen sage in the city of Varanasi, together with a great assembly of twenty thousand bhikshus.

At that time, in that city, the king was named Kritavirya. At that time, the world was at peace and prosperous, with abundant harvests, a large population, and flourishing livestock. There was no fighting or warfare, no illness or suffering, no thieves or robbers. He ruled the country with the right Dharma and was a great Dharma king.

In that country there was a young brahmin who said he had traveled far from his homeland to the south. There was a brahmin there who was well-versed in the arts and skilled in the four sciences. People from far and near all came to study with him.
At that time, the young man went to him, paid his respects, and sat to one side.
The brahmin said:
Welcome, young man!
Where do you come from?
What are you seeking?
He replied:
I come from the central country, wishing to personally receive the Way and its work under the feet of the great teacher.
The teacher asked him:
What texts do you wish to study?
He replied:
I wish to study the four sciences.
The teacher said:
Excellent!
You should study like this. This is what brahmins should do.

At that time, the young man accepted the teachings. Whenever there were students who took a break on a holiday, some would go to the river to bathe, some would go to the city to look around, and some would collect incense and firewood to use for sacrifices.
At that time, when the young man took a break on a holiday, he went with the other students to collect firewood. On the way, they asked each other:
You are all of the Brahmin caste, where do you come from?
One person replied:
I come from the east.
One person said:
I come from the western country.
One person said:
I come from the north.
At that time, the young man said:
I come from the central country.
The others asked:
We have heard a little about the other countries, but we have never heard of the customs of the central country.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
Wisdom comes from the east, and flattery is in the western country,
Respect and obedience are born in the southern countries, while harsh speech resides in the north.'
At that time, the students asked the young man:
'What is the situation in your central country?
' The young man replied:

'My central country is especially superior to other regions. Sugarcane, fragrant rice, and fruits are abundant. Livestock is plentiful, and the people enjoy happiness and peace. The population is large, and everyone values compassionate relief. They are intelligent, blessed, and their skills surpass those of others.
There is the auspicious and clean Ganges River, with its waters flowing evenly on both banks of the river.
There are eighteen places where sages reside, each practicing austerities and attaining rebirth in heaven.
' They asked again:
'Is there anyone in the central country who is as wise, eloquent, and good at debate as our teacher?
' He replied:
'There is currently a debater in the central country who is like a lion king, free and unhindered. When my teacher sees him, he feels ashamed of himself.
At that time, the young man praised the central country, and when the people heard it, they all wanted to go there.
Then the young disciples each carried firewood to their teacher's house, put down the firewood, went to their teacher, and said to him:
'This young man praises the central country, causing all of us to want to go there.'
The teacher replied:
'The beautiful things of other countries are all greatly spoken by people. You can only hear them with your ears, but it is not appropriate to go there immediately.'
The disciples said:
'That young man said that there is now a debater in the central country who is like a lion king, free and unhindered. If our teacher sees him, he will surely feel ashamed.'
The teacher replied:
'The land is rich in precious treasures and the people are very talented. How can I say within my own territory that I am the only one who is superior?'
They further said to the teacher:

'If that is the case, I now wish to leave. First, to tour the lands, second, to bathe in the celestial river, to study under the great teacher, to subdue all debates, to speak eloquently, to gain fame, and to obtain much wealth.'
At that time, the Brahmin, who had few affairs and loved his students, said to the people:
'You should take my belongings, the deer skin robe, the three-pronged staff, and the sacrificial vessels. I will now go with you to find a teacher.'
They then accepted his instructions and went together to the central country.
Wherever they arrived in the cities and towns, they held great debates. All those who came to debate were defeated, their chariots destroyed, and they returned in shame;
Or with an ash jar, they struck their heads, like crows and birds scattering when taught to shoot;
Or with silk canopies, banners, and flags, they were welcomed from far and near, all calling themselves disciples and following behind.

Having obtained wealth and prosperity, he took a new wife, and before long she gave birth to a son.
On the day of his birth, his hair was yellow and covered his head. After three weeks, he widely summoned relatives, wanting to establish a good name for his son.

When his father heard this, he immediately thought:

Their teachings are vast, profound, and difficult to fathom. Worldly debates cannot subdue them, and worldly wisdom cannot understand them. The assembly is of one mind, not seeking fame or gain. Therefore, you should not engage in debate with them.'
The son said:

At that time, the illness of the Brahmin gradually worsened. Although he received medical treatment, he became weaker and more ill each day. As it is said:
